results.title: Paper making
results.creator_credit: John Dobis, Sheridan Stumm and Discovery Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tonia Todman’s craft room”.
Tonia Todman demonstrates how to make paper. She describes how to create interesting effects through the addition of grasses, seeds, flowers, and threads to your paper pulp. How to emboss or add a watermark to your paper is also explained. As well as recycling scrap paper, Tonia demonstrates how to produce paper from leaves and other natural products, and also from rags.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Dobis, Sheridan Stumm and Discovery Video

results.title: Stencilling
results.creator_credit: John Dobis, Sheridan Stumm and Discovery Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tonia Todman’s craft room”.
Stencilling, a craft that started thousands of years ago with primitive cave painting has become increasingly popular in recent years. It is a very adaptable and creative way for the home decorator to personalise his or her home in a way that is appealing and inexpensive. Tonia Todman tells you all you need to know to be able to enhance your home with charming stencilled designs. Stencils can be applied to your walls, floors, tables, cupboards, beds, boxes, trays, fabrics, the list goes on. Their application can stretch as far as your imagination takes you, to give your home and homeware a unique, picturesque and individual touch. Tonia tells you how to plan and design a stencil, how to transfer designs, how to position and space your stencils for the most effective results, and describes painting techniques and the choice of colour schemes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Dobis, Sheridan Stumm and Discovery Video

results.title: [Children at play]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tomorrows World”.
In rebuilding outdated cities, and slums, architects have designed buildings for adults and playgrounds for children from five to fifteen. However, in studies shown here, children show a marked preference for “adventure playgrounds” which present them with risks and challenges, and the opportunity to play with children of all ages. No other credits available.

results.title: The Black death, 1361
results.creator_credit: Leo Eaton, Altug Savasal, Diane Holmes and Maryland Public Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Timeline”.
A dramatic recreation of the social upheaval experienced in the Middle Ages due to the spread of the Black Death. Modelled on a news broadcast, the program looks at the causes and impact of the Plague, and “interviews” key historical figures of the time. At its most virulent, the disease decimated both city and rural populations and created severe labour shortages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leo Eaton, Altug Savasal, Diane Holmes and Maryland Public Television

results.title: Lenin's secret files
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
‘Lenin’s secret files’ is part of an acclaimed investigative history series from the BBC which pursues new evidence and research of familiar historical events and figures. In this program the ethnic background, family, political ruthlessness and illness of Vladimir Illich Lenin, who, in 1917 led the Russian Revolution, are followed. It uses the personal archives of Lenin - which have only been accessible since the collapse of communism, to present a definitive portrait of one of history’s key figures.

group_siblings.title: A Cold war
group_siblings.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, Lionheart TV International and BBC

results.title: The African trade
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
Between the sixteenth and nineteenth century, 12,000 million Africans were sold as slave labour. The sheer number of people made it the biggest example of forced migration. Accompanying a tour of African Americans tracing their painful past, this documentary postulates that the Trans-Atlantic slave trade was only made possible by the existence of a prolific slave trade already in Africa. This resulted in the formation of mutually beneficial partnerships between Europeans and Africans. Europe and America would benefit in the long term from the arrangement, but West Africa would be left with little, only a guilt which is often not acknowledged. Narrated by Josette Simon.
